PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: EDWARD E. KUHN
Address: RATINGER, SK.
Birthplace: NORWAY

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1937
   Where did you set up housekeeping? RATINGER, SK.
   Where had you been living before that? M.L.O.
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
   How far was it to your nearest store? 20 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? once a month or so.
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Coffee, tea, sugar, flour, oats, corn, flour, etc., wheat flour & grits, about the same as at present.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household
   In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb. bags
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50

   Whole wheat flour? .......................................................

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Rabbit, beef, pork, etc.
How did you get fresh meat? By hunting.
How often did you get fresh meat? As often as we could get it.
Did you preserve meat? Yes.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood?
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? Yes.
What kinds?

What part did fish play in the family diet? As often as we could get it.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Both.
Kinds? "Gold eyes," bunker, etc.
